options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: B

options.label: D
options.text: Directly proportional for low pressure and inversely proportional for high pressure

title: Why do competitors open their stores next to one another? - Jac de Haan

multiple-choice.question: What is the main concept explained by Hotelling's Model of Spatial Competition?

options.label: A
options.text: The socially optimal solution for businesses to distribute their services throughout a community.

options.label: B
options.text: The clustering of similar companies in groups.

options.label: C
options.text: The importance of marketing strategies in competing with other businesses.

options.label: D
options.text: The need for businesses to differentiate their product line.

multiple-choice.question: What is the initial agreement between the two ice cream vendors in the model?

options.label: A
options.text: To set up their carts at the center of the beach.

options.label: B
options.text: To split the beach in half and set up their carts a quarter mile south and north of the center.

options.label: C
options.text: To compete with each other by offering different flavors of ice cream.

options.label: D
options.text: To serve all the beachgoers at the same time.

multiple-choice.question: What is the outcome of the competition between the two ice cream vendors?

options.label: A
options.text: One of them goes out of business.

options.label: B
options.text: They both end up at the center of the beach, back to back, each serving 50% of the ice-cream-hungry beachgoers.

options.label: C
options.text: They decide to merge their businesses.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the point where neither of the two ice cream vendors can improve their position by deviating from their current strategy?
Why do businesses prioritize minimizing competition and maximizing their own sales?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is the socially optimal solution.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is the Nash Equilibrium.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it allows them to compete with marketing strategies, differentiate their product line, and offer price cuts.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is the only way to survive in the market.

multiple-choice.question: What is the scenario used to explain Hotelling's Model of Spatial Competition?

options.label: A
options.text: Two ice cream vendors competing to sell ice cream to beachgoers along a one-mile stretch of beach.

options.label: B
options.text: Two fast food chains competing to serve customers at a mall.

options.label: C
options.text: Two clothing boutiques competing to sell clothes to customers at a shopping center.

options.label: D
options.text: Two mobile phone kiosks competing to sell phone plans to customers at a mall.

multiple-choice.question: Why do customers at either end of the beach have to walk further than necessary to get a sweet treat in the Nash Equilibrium?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the two ice cream vendors are competing with each other.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the two ice cream vendors are not competing with each other.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the two ice cream vendors are not serving all the beachgoers.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the two ice cream vendors are serving all the beachgoers.

multiple-choice.question: What is the socially optimal solution for the two ice cream vendors?

options.label: A
options.text: To serve all the beachgoers at the same time.

options.label: B
options.text: To serve all the beachgoers without making them walk further than necessary.

options.label: C
options.text: To compete with each other by offering different flavors of ice cream.

options.label: D
options.text: To serve all the beachgoers at the same time without making them walk further than necessary.

multiple-choice.question: Why do businesses like to keep their competition as close as possible?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it allows them to compete with marketing strategies, differentiate their product line, and offer price cuts.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it allows them to serve all the customers at the same time.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it allows them to minimize competition and maximize their own sales.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it allows them to differentiate their product line and offer price cuts.

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate outcome of the competition between the two ice cream vendors?

options.label: A
options.text: One of them goes out of business.

options.label: B
options.text: They both end up at the center of the beach, back to back, each serving 50% of the ice-cream-hungry beachgoers.

options.label: C
options.text: They decide to merge their businesses.

title: The power of a great introduction - Carolyn Mohr

options.label: C

options.label: A
options.text: To provide background information on the topic

options.label: B
options.text: To analyze the text and provide evidence

options.label: C
options.text: To serve as the foundation for the rest of the essay

options.label: D
options.text: To summarize the main points of the essay

options.label: C

options.label: C
options.text: To analyze their relationships with other characters

options.label: D
options.text: To understand their motivations and actions

options.label: A
options.text: To summarize the plot of a novel or poem

options.label: B
options.text: To provide background information on the author and their work

options.label: C
options.text: To analyze and interpret the text and its meaning

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What should be considered when writing the introduction of a literary analysis essay?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The historical context and social background of the text

options.label: C
options.text: The plot and characters of the text

options.label: A
options.text: To engage the reader and make them want to read more

options.label: B
options.text: To provide background information on the topic

options.label: C
options.text: To analyze the text and provide evidence

options.label: D
options.text: To summarize the main points of the essay

multiple-choice.question: What is the recommended approach to writing a thesis statement?

options.label: A
options.text: To start with a general statement and then narrow it down

options.label: B
options.text: To ask questions about the text and derive a thesis statement

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What should be included in a literary analysis essay?

options.label: B
options.text: A summary of the plot and characters

options.label: C
options.text: An analysis and interpretation of the text

options.label: D
options.text: A historical context and social background

options.label: A
options.text: To engage the reader and make them want to read more

options.label: B

title: Making sense of spelling - Gina Cooke

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's main argument about English spelling?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a random and irregular system.

options.label: B
options.text: It makes perfect sense when understood in the context of its structure and history.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a complex system that is difficult to understand.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a simple system that is easy to learn.

multiple-choice.question: What is the metaphor used to describe the process of understanding a word's structure and history?

options.label: A
options.text: Peeling back the layers of a cake.

options.label: B
options.text: Peeling back the layers of an onion.

multiple-choice.question: What is the base element of the word "one"?
What is the suffix added to the base element O-N-E to form the word "onion"?
What is the meaning of the word "atone"?

options.label: C
options.text: To be at one again with whomever we hurt.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's argument about the word "onion"?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a word with a random and irregular spelling.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a word that is derived from the base element O-N-E and the suffix I-O-N.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a word that is not related to the concept of oneness.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a word that is not commonly used in English.

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept of morphological relatives?

options.label: A
options.text: Words that share the same base element.

options.label: B
options.text: Words that have the same suffix.

options.label: C
options.text: Words that have the same prefix.

options.label: D
options.text: Words that have the same meaning.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's argument about English being a single, unified writing system?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a system with many different writing styles.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a system with many different languages.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a system with many layers.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a system that is shared across time and space.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's main point about spelling?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a random and irregular process.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a complex process that requires understanding of structure and history.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a simple process that can be learned quickly.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a process that is not important in language.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's final statement about English spelling?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a system that is difficult to understand.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a system that is not logical.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a system that is worth understanding.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a system that is not important.

title: The art of the metaphor - Jane Hirshfield

multiple-choice.question: What is a metaphor?

options.label: A
options.text: A way of talking about one thing by describing something else.

options.label: B
